div1.p: Carter provides camp and family news.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, April 29, 1888
div1.p:
I am practically out of Quarantine
for a few days - about 7 I suppose, & am releived
Also I am pretty well through with my arrange-
ments for the summer. when on I have the attendants
engaged & plans etc all determined on & having the prob-
ability of shooting a pilot or so- Henry by an inspired mispro-
nounciation calls them “pirotes”“pirots” -, apprehend but little
trouble officially. Well if L & the children could be pro-
vided for comfortably elsewhere I would be fairly satisfiedcontented. They do not add
to my satisfaction by staying but, although an added
care, it is possibly best.
I have settled all that now very satisfactorily if, or when
Yellow Fever comes they will go to the L'azarette, across
the Lagoon - which I can isolate

I am suffering from indigestion to some extent, otherwise
well, H. is getting to eat again &, except this morning. L. Jr.
keeps perfectly well L. Sr. also keeps up very well.
It has been too cold the past week to bathe or to fish but the children have fallen in so often that they have hardly missed their bath a long (5
days) south easterly storm, but except fleas & days mosqui-
toes it has freed the Iland of flying bugs. - (fleas don't fly I know)
I had become quite used to rowing & can go one or 2 miles with as
little fatigue (&quicker than) as walking & quicker.

The children & Barbara catch quite a number of catfish
which are very poor eating - & I caught one red fish -
about 8 lbs - over which the family rejoiced. They
are funny children. H. doesn't like any thing “thrilling”
& stayed out among the mosquitoes until he was nearly
devoured- “cause Papa was telling sister about Fafnir”,
in the house. At the same time his own propositions are
blood curdling in the extreme - do you remember when he wan-
ted me to cut the cooks head off for throwing at a chicken?
He is a brave tenderhearted little fellow & as truly polite as I ever saw anyone
Both consider Quarantine a tame affair, because I
“haven't shot anybody yet”. L's idea of the reason why
Fafnir & other Dragon's & Giants never ate the Princess
according to threat is that he could get a great many knights
& princes who would come to get the Princess & “he kept her
for bait I think Papa”, evidently a deduction from her fishing
experience. I have required for a seine & about July or August will
get some fish I suppose. There is some more in the Chande-
leur affair what I don't know, possibly we can move into extem-
poraneous quarters in July or August. As for ice we can't get it,
we will go for the mail once a week after May 10th & get a month's supply
of provisions at a time. One thing I see, about Miss. at all events, that
state officers are in quarantine matters, about as rotten as set as can
be & the shipping is deeply in the blues
about the change of the station.
I have sent John no money since he has been
at Billings, he carried $210, with him. Poor boy I was very anxious for him to
recover.
